title: Talk Money with Tony Field – September 24, 2015
text:
12:25 p.m. 
Fonterra has delivered some good news to its farmers. 
It has lifted its forecast farmgate milk price for this season by 75 cents to $4.60 per kilogram of mild solids. It is expecting to pay a dividend of between 40 and 50 cents, meaning a total payment for fully shared up farmers of $5 to $5.10. 
The good news for farmers has been delivered three days after Fonterra announced more bad news for its management staff. Job losses from its management team will now total around 750, an increase of over 200 from its previous estimates. 
It also says it expects that production volumes for this season will be 5 percent down on last season. 
The co-operative lifted the forecast payment as part of its annual profit result. It has announced a net after tax profit of $506 million for the year to July 31st. That is an increase of 183 percent. 
Fonterra also confirmed a final cash payout of $4.65 for the 2015 season for a 100 percent share-backed farmer. That includes a farmgate milk price of $4.40 per kilogram of milk solids and a dividend of 25 cents per share. 
Chairman John Wilson says Fonterra's entire business had been affected by "extremely challenging trading conditions globally". 
"Falling global dairy prices due to a supply and demand imbalance impacted the milk price, while the dividend reflected higher funding costs following significant investment in capacity to support milk growth in New Zealand, essential investments in the key strategic market of China, and the costs of maintaining a higher advance rate through the season," he says. 
"The strengthening of performance in the second half resulted in normalised earnings before interest and tax almost doubling, with good growth in our consumer and food service businesses and the results of a major push in our ingredients business to offset low milk prices with improved margins." 
Chief executive Theo Spierings says prices are "often cyclical", but this year's market is one of the most difficult he has known. 
"The global dairy industry has been hit simultaneously by geopolitical turmoil in the Middle East and Russia, Ebola in Africa, an economic slowdown in China and the sharp drop in oil and mineral prices," he says. 
"These events suppressed demand at a time when farmers all around the world had ramped up production in response to previous high prices. This resulted in an inevitable impact on pricing. 
"Looking ahead, this uncertainty means that world markets are likely to be difficult in the medium-term" 
But he says the co-operative will be ready, 
"That's because we have thoroughly reviewed our execution of strategy, our processes and working practices to embed long-term change. We are focusing all our resources to make us faster, more efficient, and achieve sustainable results." Volkswagen chief executive resigns 
Volkswagen's share price has rallied 5 percent following the resignation of chief executive Martin Winterkorn. 
But the rally came after a sell-off that saw the company lose around a third of its value, wiping 23 billion Euro (NZ$41 billion) from its market capitalisation. 
Mr Winterkorn said he had no idea about the efforts to cheat emissions standards and was "shocked by the events of the past few days". 
"Above all, I am stunned that misconduct on such a scale was possible in the Volkswagen Group," he says. 
His successor will be appointed later this week. Some have suggested it might be Porsche president and chief executive Matthias Muller. But other possibilities include Audi chief executive Rupert Stadler and VW brand head Herbert Diess. 
It is likely more people will be forced out of VW by the scandal. The company has itself filed a complaint with the German prosecutors. 
Volkswagen has set aside 6.5 billion Euro (NZ$11.65billion) for potential litigation. To put that figure in perspective VW made a 12.6 billion Euro profit last year (NZ$22 billion). 
But analysts are already saying VW might need to double that 6.5 billion figure. 
Putting a number on the real cost is tricky. It has been suggested that VW faces potential costs of US$18 billion (NZ$29 billion). 
But that figure is just an estimate. It was based on the initial figure of 482,000 four-cylinder VW and Audi (owned by VW) cars sold in the US since 2008. VW faces a maximum fine of US$37,500 for each non-compliant vehicle. 
VW will want to settle with the Environmental Protection Agency as quickly as possible. 
There is also the potential for various US states and individuals to file lawsuits, and for other countries to take action. 
Then there is the question of brand damage. How quickly will customers forgive or forget? Why would anyone in VW think they could cheat the US testing regime? 
One theory put forward is that the on-board vehicle emission controls degraded the cars' performance when the controls were activated. It made the engines hotter, and shortened their life span. The controls possibly affected torque and acceleration. 
This meant that the vehicles were not achieving the ideal combination of driving performance, fuel efficiency and environmental standards. 
Diesel vehicles make up around 3 percent of the market in the US and around 17 percent in New Zealand. 
But they are 50 percent of the market in Europe. 
There have been concerns in Europe that a number of manufacturers have been gaming the testing system and that on road performance is nothing like the lab results. 
That's raised the prospect of tougher tests. Add to that the prospects of a slowing Chinese economy and it is no wonder that investors are wary of investing in the auto sector right now. China slowdown 
The last 24 hours has seen a new wave of concern about the Chinese economy. 
China's manufacturing sector just had its worst month in over six years. 
The purchasing managers' index fell to 47 – anything below 50 means factory output is contracting. 
It is the seventh month in a row it has slowed. 
The figure has been released as China's President is visiting the United States, hoping to reassure people about the health of the Chinese economy. 
In a speech he said that the economy was "still operating within the proper range". 
Here is my talk with Paul Henry about China's latest manufacturing numbers. The markets 
The disappointing Chinese factory numbers saw the Asian markets lose ground yesterday. 
China's Shanghai Composite lost 2.16 percent. 
Japan's Nikkei closed 1.96 percent lower. 
But European markets clawed back early losses to finish higher. 
Germany's DAX gained 0.44 percent, London's FTSE rallied 1.62 percent and France's CAC 40 made a narrow gain of 0.10 percent. 
US stocks finished slightly negative. 
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.31 percent. 
The S&P500 was down 0.20 percent and the NASDAQ lost 0.08 percent. 
West Texas crude fell 4 percent to US$44.48. 
That was after a new report showing that since the end of the US summer driving season there has been a lift in gasoline inventories. 
European Brent was down 2.59 percent to $47.80. 
Gold rose $5.40 to US$1130 per ounce. 
But platinum is at a fresh six and a half year low. It slipped 0.8 percent to US924.50, due to the concern about the VW scandal. Platinum is used in diesel catalysts to clean up emissions. The dollar 
The New Zealand dollar has lost 0.8 percent against the US dollar, trading at 62.42 cents at 8am. 
By 9.40 it had edged up to 62.75 cents, following the release of the Fonterra result at 8.30am. 
The Kiwi gained over half a percent overnight against the Australian, sitting at 89.31 cents by 8am. 
By 9:40am it was 89.61 cents. 
It was 40.96 Pence at 8am, moving up to 41.16 cents. 
It was 55.82 Euro at 8am and 56.10 by 9:40am. 
It had moved from 75.06 Yen at 8am to 75.44 just over an hour and a half later.
